Name: Sale and processing of catalytic converters.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the purchase of catalytic converters
BodyName: Committee on Consumer and Worker Protection

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer and Worker Protection

Attachments.Name: Minutes of the Stated Meeting - June 16, 2022

Summary: This bill would require that any dealer in second-hand articles, or anyone else purchasing a catalytic converter for commercial purposes, must first obtain from the seller information about the vehicle the catalytic converter was removed from, which shows that the seller either owns the vehicle or was otherwise authorized to remove the catalytic converter in connection with a repair. In addition, the purchaser would be required to determine if the catalytic converter presented is consistent with one removed from the identified vehicle. The purchaser would be required to retain records of this information for at least five years. A violation of these requirements would be grounds for the suspension or revocation of any license issued by a city agency.
Text:
Be it enacted by the Council as follows:
      Section 1. Subchapter 11 of title 20 of the administrative code of the city of New York is amended by adding a new section 20-268.7 to read as follows:
      � 20-268.7 Purchase of catalytic converters. a. Before any dealer in second-hand articles as defined by this subchapter, or any person who for commercial purposes rather than personal use, purchases any catalytic converter, such dealer or person must receive the following information from the seller and determine that the catalytic converter is consistent with the manufacturer's specifications for a catalytic converter from the vehicle identified in such information:
      1. The year, make, model and vehicle identification number for the vehicle from which the catalytic converter was removed; and
      2. A copy of the certificate of title or other documentation indicating that the seller has an ownership interest in the vehicle described in paragraph 1, or where the seller is the owner of a garage or repair shop and the catalytic converter was removed in connection with a repair of the vehicle, the name and address of the vehicle's owner and copies of all related invoices.
      b. Purchasers shall maintain a written or electronic record of the information provided pursuant to subdivision a for a minimum of five years from the date the information was provided. Such records shall be open to the inspection by the department, the fire department or the police department. 
      c. In addition to the penalties provided pursuant to section 20-275, any violation of this section shall be grounds for the suspension or revocation of any license issued pursuant to this subchapter or any other license issued by any agency.
      � 2. This local law takes effect 60 days after it becomes law.
